title: 110_hr7196
content: The "Farm Relief Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title for this Act. This Act includes provisions for 2008 crop disaster assistance. Section 9001 of the U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans' Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act, 2007 is amended to provide emergency financial assistance to producers on a farm that incurred losses for the 2008 crop due to a natural disaster. The Secretary is authorized to provide sugar and sugarcane disaster assistance to processors in Florida for crop and other losses due to a natural disaster in 2008. In 2008, an agreement was made for payments similar to those in the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Hurricane Disasters Assistance Act of 2005. Louisiana is also included in the compensation for losses. In 2008, an agreement was made for payments similar to those in the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Hurricane Disasters Assistance Act of 2005, including compensation for losses in Louisiana. Secretary to provide necessary sums for assistance to first processors of sugarcane affected by natural disasters in Louisiana, eligible for loans under the Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996. The Commodity Credit Corporation provides assistance to compensate producers and first processors for crop and other losses due to natural disasters, as determined by the Secretary. Assistance is shared by affected first processors with affected producers who provide commodities to the processor. The Commodity Credit Corporation provides assistance to compensate producers and first processors for crop and other losses due to natural disasters. Assistance is shared by affected first processors with affected producers for individual losses experienced, including saltwater intrusion, flooding, wind damage, or increased planting. The Commodity Credit Corporation provides assistance to compensate producers and first processors for crop and other losses due to natural disasters, including planting, replanting, or harvesting costs. The first processor transfers the assistance to affected producers without regard to contractual share arrangements, as determined by the Secretary. The Commodity Credit Corporation compensates producers and first processors for crop losses due to natural disasters by conveying commodities from its inventory or making monetary payments to the first processor. The Commodity Credit Corporation compensates producers and first processors for crop losses through commodities or monetary payments. The Secretary uses the same base year for determining crop loss as elected by producers under the hurricane assistance program. Additional appropriations are made for Texas. The Secretary is appropriated necessary funds to assist sugarcane growers in Texas by making a payment to a farmer-owned cooperative sugarcane processor for costs incurred due to natural disasters in 2008. Producers who accept this assistance are not eligible for supplemental agricultural disaster assistance for the same crop loss. The Secretary is appropriated funds to assist sugarcane growers in Texas for crop loss due to natural disasters in 2008. Producers who accept this assistance are not eligible for additional agricultural disaster assistance under specific acts. Aquaculture grants are addressed in Section 3. The term "eligible applicant" refers to animal producers under a specific section of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. The Secretary of Agriculture will allocate $50,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for grants to State departments of agriculture to assist eligible applicants with feed costs or losses due to natural disasters. The Secretary is responsible for ensuring proper distribution of the funds. The Secretary of Agriculture may allocate funds equitably among states for documented feed use assistance without following certain rulemaking procedures. The Secretary of Agriculture can allocate funds among states for feed use assistance without following certain rulemaking procedures, including public participation and congressional review under specific laws.
